items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are rising on the River Blackwater and The Cove Brook as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and farmland is possible tomorrow morning 10/03/23, especially in the Swallowfield area area. Levels started to rise steadily yesterday due to the heavy rainfall after a drier period and are expected to continue to respond to the showers.

Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next day. We expect river levels to rise until Friday.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 10/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on Thursday morning.
Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rain and snowfall in the Dartmoor area. This has meant that the River Taw is now rising. 
Flooding to low lying land and roads close to local rivers around Jacobstowe, Okehampton and North Tawton from around 9:30am on Thursday is possible. 
We expect river levels to remain high throughout the day although no flooding to properties is forecast and warnings are not expected to be issued.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Thursday evening or earlier if the situation changes.

Friday's early morning tide at 00:45 on 10/03/2023 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with light South Westerly Force 4 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.50 m. The total forecast tide is 6.18 metres Chart Datum (3.13 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. Friday's afternoon tide is forecast to be 30 cm lower. Flood risk should then reduce through to next week, as tide levels fall through a neap cycle. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. We will remove this message by 11:00 on 10/03/2023.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Dernford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall and snowmelt. Consequently, flooding is possible later this evening and into tomorrow, 09/03/2023 and 10/03/2023. We expect flooding to affect the River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.
 
This message will be updated  tomorrow morning, 10/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected from 4 am today 10 March 2023 and will continue overnight into 11 March 2023.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads is expected around Forest Row, Ashurst, Hartfield and Penshurst particularly on and around Balls Green and Ashurst.  

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until 6 am on 11 March 2023 .

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses between and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded

This message will be updated  this evening, 10 March 2023, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.

Therefore, flooding of footpaths and farmland is possible later this evening 09/03/23, especially in the Godalming and Bordon areas. Levels started to rise steadily yesterday due to the heavy rainfall after a drier period and are expected to continue to respond to the showers particularly on the Hell Ditch. 
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next day. We expect river levels to rise until tomorrow afternoon.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 10/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible from 2pm Thursday 9th March.
Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rain and snowfall in the East Devon area. This has meant that the Rivers Clyst and Culm are now rising. 
Flooding to low lying land and roads close to local rivers around Cullompton, Willand, Culmstock, Hemyock, Bradninch, Broadclyst and Clyst St Mary from around 2pm on Thursday is possible. 
We expect river levels to remain high throughout the day and overnight. Although no flooding to properties is currently forecast, we will monitor and issue any warnings if necessary.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

The River Ouse is high and rising. In the last 2 days, more than half a month's rain (30mm) has been recorded at Barcombe. From 07:00 10/03/2023 Barcombe Mills road is likely to be affected by flood water, and could become impassable. It is possible minor flooding could also affect the Anchor Inn and gardens of properties at Barcombe Mills. Minor flood impacts could also affect rural roads, including Sloop Lane, Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge. Only isolated showers are forecast over the next 2 days but further persistent rain is currently predicted on Sunday. The river should begin to fall by 17:00 Friday evening (10/03/2023) but will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the next week. Flood impacts should begin to slowly ease when river levels start to fall. Some roads may become impassable, including Barcombe Mills road, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 18:00 10/03/2023.

Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible between 10:00 on 09/03/2023 and 10:00 tomorrow, 10/03/2023.  We expect flooding to affect the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole.   
Further showery rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to rise until 10:00 on 10/03/2023.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking and clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.

items.message:
Flooding is possible on Thursday 9th March from around 17:00 through in to Friday 10th.

Following heavy rainfall through the day river levels are responding with further rain forecast overnight, especially over high ground where larger totals are possible. The persistent rain is forecast to clear during Friday morning however risk of further heavy showers remains.

This may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to the rivers. We expect river levels to remain high throughout this period, though no flooding to properties is currently expected.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.â€¯ We are monitoring river levels and will update this message by 11am on Friday or as the situation changes

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Bradford on Avon gauge at Bradford on Avon  as a result of heavy rainfall and snow melt, with approximately 20mm of rain fallen in the last 48 hours. River levels on the River Avon at Great Somerford, River Avon at Bradford on Avon, River Avon at Bathford and Semington Brook at Semington are rising through this evening (the 09 March 2023). Currently we are not forecasting flood warning thresholds to be met. 

This message will be updated on Friday the 10th March 2023, or as the situation changes.

We expect flooding to effect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. We are closely monitoring the situation.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.86mAOD at 16:00 on 09/03/2023 and 4.77mAOD at 04:00 on 10/03/2023.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 95 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 10/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

We are currently experiencing high tides. We are in a period of Spring tides and are expecting higher than normal water levels  First forecast high water is 22:51 on 09/03/23 with a level of 1.36 mAOD. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Christchurch Harbour. mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to footpaths, minor roads and low lying land is possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.

We will continue to monitor the situation and install barriers if required..  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated Friday, 10/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message:
As a result of mini-spring tides and surge conditions, overtopping waves and spray are forecast for this evening, Thursday 09/03/2023 and Friday morning 10/03/2023. The period of risk is from 05:30 PM to 09:00 PM on Thursday and 06:00 AM to 09:00 AM on Friday. 
Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast from Mappleton to Spurn Point.
The forecast is for westerly winds throughout this afternoon and overnight into Friday, 10/03/2023.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 10/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Cornwall coast from Lands End to Chapel Porth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the morning high tide on Friday 10th March. High water at St Ives is at 06:46, times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Strong north westerly winds up to force 8 and offshore wave heights exceeding 5m are forecast and could cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations including St Ives Harbour, Portreath Harbour, and the Causeway at Hayle. 

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. 

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and will update this information by 11am on Friday. 

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Newlyn on Friday morning is 2.47mAOD.

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.

Forecast stormy weather conditions and high tide levels are expected to impact the seafront as a result of high spring tides and strong winds.  Tides will be at their highest at 19:30 today, 09/03/23. Flooding to the promenade/seafront is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  Any flooding could affect the Hunstanton seafront.
   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.  
The local Authority are closing the flood gates at Hunstanton which will make access difficult.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it: the predicted astronomical tide level is 3.86 mAODN. The forecast surge height is 0.33m. Including a forecast adjustment of 0.10m. The final forecast tide level is 4.29 mAOD. The forecast wind direction is easterly. The forecast wind strength is Force 7.

This message will be updated  this evening, 09/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Isle of Sheppey and coast from Kemsley to Seasalter
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
A Flood Alert has been issued for the coast of the Isle of Sheppey and the coast from Kemsley to Seasalter as a result of the high tide expected tomorrow afternoon. The tide will be at its highest between 1:30pm and 3:15pm tomorrow, 10/03/2023. High tide is expected at 2:15pm. The forecast water level at Sheerness is 3.53m AOD. Areas of concern include Faversham and Conyer and low lying land nearest the sea such as promenades and coastal footpaths.
Once the high tide tomorrow afternoon has passed, conditions are expected to improve from 4pm onwards. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are operating our defences and structures at Queenborough Barrier and Front Brents and Canal Basin.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads between, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow, 10/02/2023.

items.description: Tidal Medway, Medway estuary and Isle of Grain
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
A Flood Alert has been issued for the Medway estuary as a result of the high tide expected tomorrow afternoon. The tide will be at its highest between 1:30pm and 3:15pm tomorrow, 10/03/2023. High tide is expected at 2:15pm. The forecast water level at Sheerness is 3.53m AOD. Areas of concern include Upnor and Canal Road, Strood, and low lying land nearest the sea such as promenades and coastal footpaths.
Once the high tide tomorrow afternoon has passed, conditions are expected to improve from 4pm onwards. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are operating our defences and structures at Queenborough Barrier and Front Brents and Canal Basin.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads between, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow, 10/02/2023.

Friday's early morning tide at 00:51 on 10/03/2023 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with light Southerly Force 3 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.61 m. The total forecast tide is 5.25 metres Chart Datum (2.52 mAOD) at Portsmouth. For 1 hour either side of high water, levels will be high at South Street and Queen Street Emsworth. The Ship Inn car park at Langstone will flood. Water will flow into the road at Langstone High Street, although flood depths will be relatively shallow, and flooding will only cause impacts nearest to the harbour front. After this tide, levels will reduce and no further impacts are expected. In Emsworth, we will lower levels in the Mill Pond and install drop boards to protect property. If you have it, and live directly on the harbour front, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. We will remove this message by 10:00 on 10/03/2023.

The forecast tide level for Friday's early morning tide at 00:18 on 10/03/2023 and 02:36 on 10/03/2023 has increased. This increase is due to unsettled weather with light South Westerly Force 4 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.66 m. The total forecast tide is 4.20 metres Chart Datum (2.20 mAOD) at Beaulieu. For 30 minutes either side of high water, the tide will flood into the garden of the mill house on the downstream side of the Mill Pond. Minor road flooding at Palace Lane is also expected, making access to the village temporarily more difficult. After this tideâ€š levels will reduce and no further impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. For safety, please take care if walking or driving through Beaulieu. The incoming tide will flood the main road quickly. We will remove this message by 10:00 on 10/03/2023.

Friday's early morning tide at 01:00 on 10/03/2023 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with light South Westerly Force 4 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.5 m. The total forecast tide is 5.24 metres Chart Datum (2.50 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. For 1 hour either side of high water, the tide will flood Shore Road. At Bosham High Street, water will be near to or flood front door steps. Gardens or land of shore side properties around the harbour could also be affected. Friday's afternoon tide is forecast to be 40 cm lower. Flood risk should then reduce through to next week, as tide levels fall through a neap cycle. We continue to monitor the forecast. As a precaution, if you have them, please install flood boards 1 hour before high tide. Avoid walking through flood water as it may contain hidden hazards and be deep in places. We will remove this message by 11:00 on 10/03/2023.

items.description: South Devon coast from Dawlish Warren to Seaton
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:

Strong force 7 north westerly winds and offshore wave heights of 3.9m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations around Seaton.  Expect tides to be around 60mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue an update on Friday afternoon or earlier if required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Exmouth is 1.95 mAOD, this is  6cm above astronomical tide level.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
A tidal surge and Spring tides could increase the water levels around high water and overtopping of sea defences is possible.  Forecast high water is 08:00 on 10/03/2023 with a Force 6 North Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Weymouth, for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  The flood alert is triggered at Preston Beach. Flooding is possible at Castletown, Preston Beach, Poole Harbour, Bournemouth Beach, Hengistbury Head and Christchurch Harbour   

We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads.  
This message will be updated Friday, 10/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

A tidal surge coinciding with spring tides will increase the water levels around high water and overtopping of sea defences is possible. The flood alert criteria are triggered from the Chiswell Beach.  Forecast high water is 07:45 on 10/03/2023 with a Force 6 Northwesterly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Portland Tidal gauge, for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect Charmouth, Seatown, Bothenhampton, Burton Freshwater, Burton Bradstock, Cogdean Beach, Chesil Beach, West Fleet, East Fleet and Chiswell   

We are closely monitoring the situation
Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads.  
This message will be updated tomorrow, 10/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Warwick Old Budbrooke Road river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall and snow melt.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible to begin between 01:00 and 02:00 Friday morning, 10/03/23.  Flooding is affecting Properties along Lodge Crescent.
Further rainfall and snow is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high throughout Friday 10/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please activate any property flood protection products you may have, such as flood barriers and air brick covers and avoid contact with flood water.  Call 999 if in immediate danger.
This message will be updated by 09:00 on 10/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Hamerton river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property/roads and farmland is possible today, 10/03/23.  Flooding is affecting Alconbury Brook at Hamerton, The Alconburys, Little Stukley and Brampton   
  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.  

This message will be updated  in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

The River Adur is high and rising. Since Wednesday, 35mm of rain has been recorded at Cowfold, which is more than half a month's rain. From 05:30 10/03/2023 flooding could affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. As well as extensive water in fields, flooding could also affect gardens of properties near Mock Bridge and may begin to approach buildings too. Only isolated showers are forecast over the next 2 days, but further persistent rain is currently predicted on Sunday. The river should begin to fall by 14:00 10/03/2023. Flood impacts should begin to slowly ease when river levels start to fall, however the river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the next week. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 16:00 10/03/2023.
